720151f-a.text:
Greenwich Ave, west side, north from and including the S.W. corner of 10th Street, to but not including Charles Street. This view also shows 10th Street, north side, from but not including Patchin Place, to and including Greenwich Ave, The excavation in the foreground is for the new municipal women's jail on the site of old Jefferson Market
Courts.
December 14, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

711046f-b.text:
(1)
Jefferson Market Courthouse and clock tower, with the excavation
on the site of the old jail and the law and bail bond offices
on the north side of 10th Street (formerly Amos Street), from
Greenwich Avenue to Sixth Avenue.
The courthouse, on the S.W. corner of Sixth Avenue and 10th Street,
was erected in 1875. Prior to that there was a tall, roundish
wooden tower, rather like a lighthouse in appearance, on the
same site. The new House of Detention for Women is to be built
in 1930-31, to fill the rest of the triangular block in which
the courthouse stands.
The break in the north side of 10th Street is the entrance to
Patchin Place, a semi-private residential court.
December 31, 1929
P.L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing only the N.E. corner at Greenwich Avenue and
the south side to Sixth Avenue, three years later, with the new
House of Detntion for Women on the site of the old jail.
March 6, 1933
P.L. Sperr.

711048f-b.text:
(1)
10th Street (formerly Amos Street), east from and including Greenwich
Avenue, showing the Jefferson Market Courthouse and clock tower
(1875) on the S.W. corner of Sixth Avenue, and the Cushman Bakery
on the N.E. corner of Greenwich Avenue. This branch of the
Cushman chain is the original Cushman store, established in this
building in 1854.
The car track in the foreground is the westbound track of the 8th
Street crosstown surface line.
March 29, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
10th St. east of Greenwich Ave.
Neg. A-264
July 17, 1941
P.L. Sperr

711049f-b.text:
(1)
10th Street (formerly Amos Street), north side, at Greenwich Avenue,
showing the Cushman Bakery at the N.E. corner of Greenwich Avenue,
and old houses, remodelled into studio apartments, at and adjoining
the N.W. corner.
This particular Cushman store is of interest because it used to be
the original Cushman Bakery before Cushman's became an incorporated
chain, and has occupied that old brick building ever since 1854.
March 29, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A detail of view 1, showing No. 129 West 10th Street.
September 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

711045f-a.text:
West 10th Street, north side, west from 6th, to Greenwich Aves. and across Patchin Place. The buildings in the foreground are brick covered frame structures. At the rear of same are small 3 story houses that have entrances from Patchin & Mulligan Places.

March 28, 1938.
P. L. Sperr,
